turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: We'll hear argument now in Number 96-1291, Delores Oubre v. Entergy Operations, Inc.--
Ms. Haynie.

turn.speaker: barbara_g_haynie
turn.label: Ms. Barbara G. Haynie
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:

After 2 years of careful consideration, in response to a regulatory void, Congress enacted the Older Worker Benefit Protection Act to protect the rights of older workers who were in greater force leaving... being forced to leave the work place.
The Older Worker Benefit Protection Act mandates that an older worker may not waive their rights secured under the ADEA unless such waiver is knowing and voluntary as defined by the act.

If an employer chooses to utilize a waiver of age discrimination rights, Congress requires an employer to provide the older worker with the requisite information and time to assess the value of the right to be waived.

The Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals' adoption of the common law contract principles of ratification and tender-back in addressing a situation where the employer uses a waiver which is... does not comply with the Older Worker Benefit Protection Act will in all practical purpose render the act meaningless.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: What would happen in the case if the day after the release is signed, but before any money changed hands, the employer says, we've made a mistake, it's a good faith mistake, we didn't know about the ADEA, we want to rescind the release?

turn.speaker: barbara_g_haynie
turn.label: Ms. Barbara G. Haynie
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, pursuant to the statute there is a revocation period of 7 days after the release is signed.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: No, but this is the employer.

turn.speaker: barbara_g_haynie
turn.label: Ms. Barbara G. Haynie
turn.text: I understand.
There will be a 7-day--that release is not effective pursuant to--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, let's change the hypothetical.
Suppose... I want the release to be effective.

turn.speaker: barbara_g_haynie
turn.label: Ms. Barbara G. Haynie
turn.text: --7 days after it.
The employer would not have the right to rescind the release.
It is an invalid release with regard to ADEA claims if it does not comply with the statute.
If they rescind the release to all other waivers, I believe the plaintiff or the older worker will have the right to proceed against the employer.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: But in other words you couldn't have--
--doesn't have to rescind it.
Excuse me.
You couldn't have an equitable action to rescind the release at the employer's behest?
Let's assume a good faith mistake on his part.

turn.speaker: barbara_g_haynie
turn.label: Ms. Barbara G. Haynie
turn.text: No, sir.
If the waiver does not comply with the requirements of the act, it is a void waiver pursuant to--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well then, he wouldn't have to pay... he wouldn't have to pay any of the money, either?
Right.
If it's void, he wouldn't have to pay the money.

turn.speaker: barbara_g_haynie
turn.label: Ms. Barbara G. Haynie
turn.text: --Well, the problem with not having to pay the money, Your Honor, is that the waiver includes, and particularly in this case, many other actions, other than a waiver of ADEA--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: That's, it seems to me, one of the points, is that this might very well be valid as to everything but the ADEA.

turn.speaker: barbara_g_haynie
turn.label: Ms. Barbara G. Haynie
turn.text: --And I believe that--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: There's a lot of talk on void and voidable, but this covers so many claims that it seems to me that's something that may be more of a problem for the respondent than for you.

turn.speaker: barbara_g_haynie
turn.label: Ms. Barbara G. Haynie
turn.text: --I believe it would be void to the ADEA claims.
I believe that--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: As to them, then, the employer can, on day eight, say, I'm not going to pay anything insofar as it might be attributable... let's assume, keep the example, that he broke down the various considerations and said, with respect to this particular claim I'm not going to pay anything because it's void, because it violates the statute.
That would be legally proper, I take it, on your view.

turn.speaker: barbara_g_haynie
turn.label: Ms. Barbara G. Haynie
turn.text: --That's correct, Your Honor, that would be, and the plaintiff can go forward and pursue their age discrimination claim in court.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: But in order to determine how much harm we're doing by saying these things are void from the outset I think we should be realistic and know that most of them do not assign a certain amount of money to the ADEA release and a certain amount of money to various other releases, and I doubt very much, when it's not broken out that way, whether you can say the contract is valid in part and invalid as to that one little item.
I mean, this is a standard question of severability.
I don't know how you can rip that contract apart, especially when the ADEA claim is a very major part of the consideration.
Do you know any other contract that's picked apart like that where it's just partially valid and we're going to enforce all the rest of it?

turn.speaker: barbara_g_haynie
turn.label: Ms. Barbara G. Haynie
turn.text: Well, I think Congress has clearly spoken here that if the waiver drafted by the employer does not comply with the Older Worker Benefit Protection Act--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: barbara_g_haynie
turn.label: Ms. Barbara G. Haynie
turn.text: --That waiver is nonenforceable--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Therefore that portion of the contract is bad, and I would say the whole contract is bad.

turn.speaker: barbara_g_haynie
turn.label: Ms. Barbara G. Haynie
turn.text: --because I do believe the other portions of that waiver remain valid.
If the employer does not break out the enumeration for each right to be waived, that's the argument to save the set-off for the remedial phase of the trial.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: So all the employers who have these, have made these commitments can now simply stop paying money.

turn.speaker: barbara_g_haynie
turn.label: Ms. Barbara G. Haynie
turn.text: If they choose to stop paying money and have not enumerated out which moneys are going to be designated for which rights are being waived, then I believe the plaintiff has a simple right of breach of contract for all other rights that they had signed, if the money has stopped.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: No, but a contract is... you can't pick apart a contract like that.
If the contract's void, it's void.

turn.speaker: barbara_g_haynie
turn.label: Ms. Barbara G. Haynie
turn.text: Well, I--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: What do you mean, he's breached it?
How much money is he supposed to pay, two-thirds of the full contract, or... I mean, how do you decide how much?

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: The full amount?

turn.speaker: barbara_g_haynie
turn.label: Ms. Barbara G. Haynie
turn.text: --I agree, Your Honor, I believe that's one of the practical problems of this case, and that's why the tender back at the very beginning of a case to bar plaintiff to going into court is very prac... impractical.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: What I am worried about is, you are destroying cause... you are destroying entitlements to these payments on the part of all older workers who have been terminated, including the majority of them who do not have any ADEA claims.
I'm not sure you're doing them a favor.
You're saying if the employer is confident enough that this worker doesn't have an ADEA claim he can just say, I'm sorry, we made a mistake.

turn.speaker: barbara_g_haynie
turn.label: Ms. Barbara G. Haynie
turn.text: Well, I believe that's what Congress has established--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, Ms. Haynie, we aren't sure about that, because Congress did not expressly say such an agreement that fails to comply with these requirements is void, as they have done in some other legislation.
They don't say that, so at common law I suppose an agreement where the employer was guilty of some kind of fraud, duress, or coercion would be voidable, wouldn't it?

turn.speaker: barbara_g_haynie
turn.label: Ms. Barbara G. Haynie
turn.text: --That's correct.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Voidable at the option of the person defrauded.
Maybe this contract is voidable, not void.
Congress didn't say, one way or another.

turn.speaker: barbara_g_haynie
turn.label: Ms. Barbara G. Haynie
turn.text: I believe the phrase, may not waive, is tantamount to announce, or proclaiming void any waivers which do not comply with the Older Worker Benefit Protection Act for those rights secured under the ADEA.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: But why?

Why would Congress wanted to have done that, because what you're being told, I think, from Justice Scalia and others, is let's imagine... let's imagine that a... that we have 100,000 workers who are quitting, and each of them has a contract, and they all promise not to bring claims, and each of them is paid [dollars] 5,000 for that promise.
All right.
Now, very few of them will have real ADEA claims.
Very few.
But suppose they're all like this, that they didn't comply with the rule exactly.

Now, on your theory one day every employer is going to wake up to the fact that he hasn't bought a single thing for his [dollars] 5,000, and somebody might go around and collect the lawsuits and sue everybody and get the money back, so you'd be taking from 100,000 or 90 of the 100,000, [dollars] 5,000 each have to go right back.

On the other hand, if you're wrong, all that happens is when somebody has a good claim they have to put up a little bit of money up front, whatever the proportionate amount of the ADEA part is, which might be [dollars] 500, and the lawyer could front it for him.

So why would Congress want the result that you want, which would seem to put at risk hundreds of thousands of workers to have to give back the money who would have no claim... the employer would sue them... and at the same time to protect some lawyer from not having to put up a very little money up front.
Now, I'm putting it strongly, but it's exactly that practical consideration that I'm very disturbed about in terms of your position.

turn.speaker: barbara_g_haynie
turn.label: Ms. Barbara G. Haynie
turn.text: Your Honor, with regard to the practical--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: It's not practical, it's legal, and what I'm asking is, why would Congress have wanted that result?

turn.speaker: barbara_g_haynie
turn.label: Ms. Barbara G. Haynie
turn.text: --Congress was very clear in enacting this statute to protect the rights of older workers when negotiating with employers when they're forced out of the work place.
They are not arm-length negotiators.
Congress put in very specific requirements an employer must meet so that an employee knows they are giving up a valuable right in exchange for that consideration.

If they're given adequate considera... or information, and there is some specter of discrimination, then the employer can go... the employee can go back to the employer and negotiate for a greater severance or say, no, I'm not going to sign this.
Without that knowledge, and without the time to consider it in a coercion case, then the employee is really left with no option but to take the money.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: We're not talking about the same thing.
What I'm talking about is, I agree with you the contract is no good.
I agree with you the employee can sue.
I agree with you that that provision in the contract promising not to sue is worthless.
It's no good.
The question involved is whether, before he brings the lawsuit, he has to give back a proportionate share of the money that he's been paid for his promise not to sue.
I would imagine if they're paying five or [dollars] 6,000 for such a promise he'd have to give [dollars] 500 back, or... and the lawyer could put it up front.

turn.speaker: barbara_g_haynie
turn.label: Ms. Barbara G. Haynie
turn.text: Well--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: So what is the big problem about... that you're worried about?

turn.speaker: barbara_g_haynie
turn.label: Ms. Barbara G. Haynie
turn.text: --The problem is twofold, Your Honor.
First, the monetary amount could be greater.
The employee expends the money looking... for living expenses while looking for other employment.
The second problem is, who is to decide what the proportionate share will be?
That's going to have to be decided by a trier of fact, a judicial tribunal.
That means you're in court already.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, can a proportionate share be determined?
How do we determine the proportionate share?

turn.speaker: barbara_g_haynie
turn.label: Ms. Barbara G. Haynie
turn.text: The proportionate share can be determined at the end of the litigation, when a trial judge has taken into--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, I thought courts have routinely said they are unable to make that kind of a determination.
I mean, they can't do that.

turn.speaker: barbara_g_haynie
turn.label: Ms. Barbara G. Haynie
turn.text: --Well, if you--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: You get a... you either have to give it all back or none, as I see it.
I don't see how that could possibly be made.

turn.speaker: barbara_g_haynie
turn.label: Ms. Barbara G. Haynie
turn.text: --If you require the plaintiff to tender back all the money received, then it is the employer who receives the windfall there, because the employee has waived many other rights under that waiver.
The employer can raise the defense.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: But if you say the contract is void, then what you're doing is saying that the ADEA tail wags the State law dog with respect to all releases.
You are saying that all State law releases, State claim releases are, I take it, void because the contract is not severable.

turn.speaker: barbara_g_haynie
turn.label: Ms. Barbara G. Haynie
turn.text: No, I don't believe that, Your Honor.
I don't believe that.
I believe Congress spoke directly and specifically to those rights secured under the ADEA.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Ms. Haynie, suppose--

--Ms. Haynie, did... maybe I misunderstood your argument, but I thought your position was, may not waive is... leaves employer and employee without any authority, without any power to do anything with respect to the ADEA claim.
That being so, you construe this contract as though what may not be done wasn't done, so that the only thing that would be covered would be the non-ADEA claims.
Maybe you're not making that argument.

turn.speaker: barbara_g_haynie
turn.label: Ms. Barbara G. Haynie
turn.text: No, I am making that argument, Your Honor, that again the statute speaks specifically to ADEA claims, and those are the... that is the waiver that is void.
That is the waiver that is nonenforceable against the plaintiff who signs it.
All other waivers of claims can be possibly enforceable against the plaintiff, unless the plaintiff can show that it was not an involuntary waiver.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What if it was just an ADEA claim here, so that we didn't have the problem of breaking out a partial amount, and the... would you say that the employee did not have to tender it back?

turn.speaker: barbara_g_haynie
turn.label: Ms. Barbara G. Haynie
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor.
If the waiver does not comply with the statute it is an ineffective waiver.
It is a void waiver.
The plaintiff can go forward with the lawsuit, and if there is some--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: The plaintiff just gets to keep it, then?

turn.speaker: barbara_g_haynie
turn.label: Ms. Barbara G. Haynie
turn.text: --Well, there's a concern with regard to equity amongst the parties.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, there's a considerable concern.

turn.speaker: barbara_g_haynie
turn.label: Ms. Barbara G. Haynie
turn.text: It can come at the remedial phase of the trial--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, but--

turn.speaker: barbara_g_haynie
turn.label: Ms. Barbara G. Haynie
turn.text: --with either an offset--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: --Well, supposing the plaintiff loses at the trial.

turn.speaker: barbara_g_haynie
turn.label: Ms. Barbara G. Haynie
turn.text: --I believe that part of the incentive in complying with the statute is a loss of that money, the severance pay, if you do not draft a valid waiver under the Older Worker Benefits Act.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: You mean--
--That's totally contrary to any concept of the law of contracts.

turn.speaker: barbara_g_haynie
turn.label: Ms. Barbara G. Haynie
turn.text: Well, this is... we're not dealing with the law of contracts.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, you may be dealing with the law of contracts except as Congress has otherwise provided.
You're arguing for a very expansive construction of a particular language of Congress.

turn.speaker: barbara_g_haynie
turn.label: Ms. Barbara G. Haynie
turn.text: I believe, Your Honor, that it's warranted in this case.
The legislative history is replete and is quite full with Congress' intent.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: We don't ordinarily get into legislative history.

turn.speaker: barbara_g_haynie
turn.label: Ms. Barbara G. Haynie
turn.text: And I understand, Your Honor, but Congress' intent to occupy this entire area.
In fact, the respondent has conceded that in enacting this statute there is as Federal statutory standard for knowing and voluntary.
It is all-encompassing.
There is no room for judicial common law development here.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: No, but you don't have to have judicial common law development with respect to the protections of this statute, I suppose, in order to recognize that if on a void contract there is a total failure of consideration the employer at least would have the right to bring action for the return of the consideration that he has furnished, and do you deny that he would have such an action?

turn.speaker: barbara_g_haynie
turn.label: Ms. Barbara G. Haynie
turn.text: Your Honor, to require the tender back would be to engraft on the statute--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: I'm not talking about tender-backs.
I'm simply saying, let's assume that your conclusion is correct, and we recognize it.
The employer says... and by the way, we're operating here on the hypothesis that it's only the age claim that's involved.
The employer says, I got nothing.
There has been a total failure of consideration.
I want my money back.
The employer can sue for it, can't he?
He may have a tough time collecting it.

You've pointed out, and I'm sure you're right, that in most of these cases the money has been spent, but the... we don't have to deny the employer the cause of action to get the consider... to get his consideration back in order to enforce this act, do we?

turn.speaker: barbara_g_haynie
turn.label: Ms. Barbara G. Haynie
turn.text: --Well, Your Honor, there may be some State claims in restitution or unjust enrichment that the employer could bring.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: That's what I'm talking about.

turn.speaker: barbara_g_haynie
turn.label: Ms. Barbara G. Haynie
turn.text: Certainly.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: You're not denying that, are you?

turn.speaker: barbara_g_haynie
turn.label: Ms. Barbara G. Haynie
turn.text: No, certainly I'm not denying that.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Okay.

turn.speaker: barbara_g_haynie
turn.label: Ms. Barbara G. Haynie
turn.text: And to try to place the--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: And you're not denying, in fact I think you suggest it, that if your client should win, quite properly if the employer has brought his claim there could be a set-off against the recovery.

turn.speaker: barbara_g_haynie
turn.label: Ms. Barbara G. Haynie
turn.text: --That's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Ms. Haynie, could I--
--And State law might operate as well to say that it's not severable, that you can't decide how much goes to ADEA and how much consideration--
--Yes, right.
--went to these other claims.
That's possible, too, isn't it?

turn.speaker: barbara_g_haynie
turn.label: Ms. Barbara G. Haynie
turn.text: It's possible, Your Honor, but I believe the trial court will be in the best position, after all the evidence is taken in--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well--

turn.speaker: barbara_g_haynie
turn.label: Ms. Barbara G. Haynie
turn.text: --to assess the values of this claim.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --is that right?
Ms. Haynie, suppose I sell you five tickets on horses in a horse race, okay.
One of them wins.
The other four don't, okay.
Do you think that it's fair if the contract should be rescinded as to only one of those tickets, one of the losing ones, that you should get back 20 percent of your money?

turn.speaker: barbara_g_haynie
turn.label: Ms. Barbara G. Haynie
turn.text: Well, Your Honor--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I mean, that is what is called an aleatory contract, a contract that depends on future events to some extent, as does any waiver of rights.
You don't know whether the person has claims that he will sue on or not.
When he does have one, is it fair to say, well, that claim was one-fifth of the whole contract, we'll give you one-fifth of your money back?
You can't do that.
The one ticket for the winning horse is what the whole thing was about.

turn.speaker: barbara_g_haynie
turn.label: Ms. Barbara G. Haynie
turn.text: --I believe that is what the trial court is going to be charged with doing.

If you attempt to put the parties back into the places they were before the invalid waiver was offered to the employee, you must then give Ms. Oubre her lost wages, you must put her in a position again of making the decision as to whether she wants to stay with the company or leave the company, and you also must provide all the information required by the act, which the respondent has not done to date in this case.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Let me ask you a factual question.
we've all been making the same assumption here, but let me just question the assumption.

Is there any way of knowing, in the run-of-the-mill situation in which there is a release and the object, the obvious principal purpose of the release is the age claim, whether in those cases there tends to be a, in fact, others unrelated claims?
I mean, for example, in this case, was she an employee at-will, so... or was she subject to some kind of a cause requirement so that she would have had a lost wage claim?
Because if most of these releases in the real world are simply releases of nothing but the age claim, then this problem that's being raised would loom smaller than it might otherwise be.
How do we... is there any way for us to know?

turn.speaker: barbara_g_haynie
turn.label: Ms. Barbara G. Haynie
turn.text: Well, I could tell you factually for this situation she was an at-will employee, and certainly these waivers contain... I've never seen a waiver that just contains an ADEA waiver.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Right.
I'm sure that's right.

turn.speaker: barbara_g_haynie
turn.label: Ms. Barbara G. Haynie
turn.text: They contain numerous other waivers with regard to Worker's Compensation.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --be crazy not to, but in fact, do you--

turn.speaker: barbara_g_haynie
turn.label: Ms. Barbara G. Haynie
turn.text: All other waivers.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --Is there any way for us to know whether it's really covering anything else in most cases?

turn.speaker: barbara_g_haynie
turn.label: Ms. Barbara G. Haynie
turn.text: I believe that the language of the waiver--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Oh, I know what the language of the waiver says, but I mean, in fact, are there any real claims... is there any way for us to know whether there are in fact any substantial claims in most of these cases, other than the age claim?

turn.speaker: barbara_g_haynie
turn.label: Ms. Barbara G. Haynie
turn.text: --Well, if the plaintiff brings the suit, obviously, or files her claim against... files her claim with the EEOC, or, you know, the State regulatory agency--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: This would waive title VII claims, too, I suppose.
This waiver, if I remember correctly, waived any and all claims.
It didn't mention any specific ones.

turn.speaker: barbara_g_haynie
turn.label: Ms. Barbara G. Haynie
turn.text: --That's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But apart from State law claims and title VII claims raised with sex discrimination, would there be anything else that might be included in that?

turn.speaker: barbara_g_haynie
turn.label: Ms. Barbara G. Haynie
turn.text: Well, there's Workers' Compensation claims.
There could be any other causes of action that may have come up.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Ms. Haynie.
Ms. Brinkmann.

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:

To respond to the concerns that the Court has raised, we would agree that the congressional scheme that has been established here addresses these concerns in that Congress gave the courts broad equitable authority, and the Court recognized that in McKennon, that that equitable authority is something that the district courts in ADEA cases exercised to take into account concerns of employers.
That is consistent with the common law trend, also.
As respondent pointed out in its brief, the common law tender-back was not required in equity, generally.
It was only for settlement releases, and in those cases those were... the cases we've seen are ones that only had one topic of the release, so by suing you were undoing the release.
But in cases like this, this is a waiver that violates a statute.
At common law, that was one of the major bases for not enforcing a contract.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, is it void or voidable?
At common law, it would have been voidable for fraud or coercion or duress, and this is a substitute for that.
This is a statutory expression of conditions that have to be there to avoid any kind of coercion or fraud, isn't it?

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: We believe--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: So why isn't it voidable at the instance of the employee?

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: --Your Honor, we do believe it goes beyond that, the requires provision of information, a lot more protection than the common law.
Whether--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, is it void?

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: --We believe that the waiver of the ADEA claim is void, Your Honor.
At common law what they would have done with something like that, they would have applied the practice of divisibility.
When there was an illegal contract for gambling, or something that violated an antitrust statute, they would look and see if that statute was divisible.
If it was not divisible, often illegal contracts parties were left as they were.
There were some exceptions to that.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: What is it... is it divisible in most cases here, do you think?

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: I think it may very well be.
I mean, part of the thing that is even more complicated, Your Honor, much more consideration was given for the [dollars] 6,000 than an ADEA waiver.

Petitioner resigned from her job, in addition to waiving other claims, so there's a lot of equity, and that's exactly what courts of equities would look at, and that's why that decision was made at the remedy phase of the proceeding, where the court could take into account those equitable concerns, and we--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Ms. Brinkmann, if the void waiver leaves the parties where they were, then doesn't someone who is asserting that the waiver violates the statute by bringing a lawsuit, doesn't that person have to return... in order to be consistent in the pleading, doesn't the person have to return whatever money that person has acquired under the contract?

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: --Your Honor, we--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: You say it's void.

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: --No.
We believe that Congress made clear in this statute that waivers were void if they did not comply with these requirements.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: And that means that that waiver violates the statute.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: So it's an illegal waiver.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Right.
Therefore, if you assert that that has happened, you should return the money when you bring the lawsuit.

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: No, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Otherwise you're being inconsistent with your theory.

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: At common law a tender-back was just not that... all... Farnsworth, Dobbs, and all of your discussions make clear that tender-back was not that--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I don't... I don't even care about the common law.

I just care about someone who comes in and asserts that this contract is void, but wants to keep the money the person has under the contract, or at least use it to hire the lawyer to bring the lawsuit.

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: --The problem--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: And then if you lose you keep the money, but if you win, oh, I'll cough up the money, but I'll get more.

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: --The problem is the statute, Your Honor.
It's Congress.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: The Congress... the statute says nothing about this.

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: No, but--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: The statute says nothing about it.

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: --But you are creat... you would be creating another condition precedent to bringing suit, and Congress was very clear about what was required in that event, and it--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Where was that clarity manifested?

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: --We believe in--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What section of the statute?

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: --In 626, Your Honor.
It's enfolding respondent's brief in the appendix.
(f)(1) makes quite clear Congress expressly said an individual may not waive any right or claim--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: We know that, but you're saying that Congress made expressly clear that no tender back would be required.
Where is that?

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: --Well, Your Honor, we believe that--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: I thought you said Congress made expressly clear.

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: --Yes.

We believe, when you look at the... for example, (f)(3), where Congress foresaw that there would be disputes among parties about the validity of these waivers, Congress specifically said the burden would be on the employer, or the person asserting the validity of the waiver.
In this case it would be--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What does that have to do about tender back?

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: --Because tender back, Your Honor, was to put up the money to counter the presumption of the validity of the contract, and here it's to the contrary.
Congress has supplanted that, and I think it's important to--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: That certainly is not an express provision about tender back, is it?

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: --No, but Your Honor, in case--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: I thought you said it was.

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: --No, because I think that the tender back clearly conflicts with the purposes and the construct, the mechanism which Congress created.
To impose--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Ms. Brinkmann, may I ask you to address a specific point there?

I thought one of the strongest, if not the strongest argument for the position that you and the petitioner take is that if you require a tender back, the prohibition in the statute is a dead letter, because in fact you're dealing with people who are not going to have the money to tender back, not because they went to the race track because they used it to pay the rent and buy the food.
Is there anything we can look at to find out whether that... that seems to have an intuitive appeal to it.
Is... has it gotten anything more than an intuitive appeal?
Are there statistics anywhere, or is there anything in the record to the effect that that is so?

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: --Certainly, Your Honor.

In the first section of the ADEA, 621, Congress made a specific find or example that older workers are much less likely to retain and regain employment once they're terminated, so it's a specific class.
The legislative history also concerns information about that.

Also, even where courts have applied a tender-back requirement as Judge Posner did in his opinion for the Seventh Circuit in a title VII case, he recognized that where there was a situation in which living expenses would preclude the bringing of the suit, that would not be permitted as a matter of equity.
He also pointed out that, you know, perhaps an offer would be sufficient, would be offset at the remedial phase.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: In other words, I will... I offer to pay you back if I get the money from which I can do it.

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: That's an offset remedy, and I just have to urge the Court to realize that to adopt the court of appeals approach would be to put the workers exactly back where they were before enactment of the statute.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, are you saying that we have to enact as a matter of Federal common law some rule about tender-back, or do we look to State law to see what the normal contract situation would be?

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: No, Your Honor.
We believe that Congress has spoken, has established this very specific scheme--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, we... suppose we don't find an express provision in the statute governing tender-back.
Do we look to the State law where the contract was created?

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: --No, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Or do we try to create some Federal legal principle to cover this?

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: No, Your Honor.
We believe Congress created that because to impose tender-back would be nullify the statute--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, where do you get the offset authority?

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: --The equitable authority of the court.
That's clear, and this Court has, you know, agreed with that in McKennon.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Why does the court have equitable authority at the end of the case but not the beginning?

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: Congress gave it remedial authority in 626(b)... or... yes, 626(b) of the act, and made clear all the remedies that the court could give, and it's important to realize that at this point if this worker has to make a choice of whether to have the severance pay or a waiver, that worker is exactly where they were before passage of the act.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: I don't understand that.
Am I missing a... I mean, I only have one question, really, for this side of the case, and I couldn't find the answer in any brief, and it seemed so obvious I must be missing something.
That is, I absolutely take in your point that if the worker has to front the money sometimes they won't have it, and maybe their lawyer wouldn't give it to them.
I see that as a problem.
I don't think it makes the worker back at stage zero, but it could be a problem.

But if we agree with you, everyone's been pointing out that in all the millions of retirements contracts in the United States, every one that doesn't comply with all this is void, and why won't, at some day, some clever person work out that he could go from employer to employer, buy up tens of thousands of suits, and all the people who don't have ADEA claims will have to give back several thousand dollars to their employer?

I mean, it's the people who don't have the claim who vastly outnumber the ones who do, who would be suddenly left high and dry, on your theory, at the mercy of whether an employer would just decide to sue him for the money back.

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: Your Honor--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Now, that seems to me an obvious point, but no one mentions it, and therefore I must be missing something, so I want you to tell me what I'm missing.

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: --I think Your Honor is pointing out the fact that it's unclear whether a worker could even avoid this waiver if they wanted to enforce--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: No.
I'm talking about workers who don't... they're happy.
There are millions of them.

They have their contracts and they have [dollars] 6,000 to boot, and they don't have a dream of a claim, and those workers, on your theory, it seems to me, if the provision in the contract is void, are at the mercy of any lawyer working for an employer who would ask for the money back.

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: --Again, Your Honor, we don't believe so.
It's an illegal contract that is not enforceable even at the common law--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: If it's not enforceable, why... it's the fourth time I've said the exact... I must be not be saying it well.
Suppose it's not enforceable.
It's then void.
There is no such provision.
Each worker is there with [dollars] 4,000 that he got.
Why can't the employer just sue him to get the [dollars] 4,000 back?
He was unjustly enriched.

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: --Your Honor, may I answer?

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: At common law there could... we don't want to preclude that there would never be an unjust enrichment situation.

Perhaps it was some egregious unjust enrichment, but at common law those would have been exceptions to the principle that illegal contracts were against public policy and the parties were left as they were.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Ms. Brinkmann.

turn.speaker: beth_s_brinkmann
turn.label: Ms. Beth S. Brinkmann
turn.text: Thank you, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Mr. Phillips, we'll hear from you.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:

It seems to me that the bulk of the discussion that's gone on today suggests as strongly as anything that I could propose to you why it is that we would do far better to leave the common law in place, providing us with a set of guideposts that can be applied on a regular basis and on a case-by-case basis, and recognize that section 626(f) is a very pointed--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Mr. Phillips, let me just raise a question that... you know somebody's got to ask you a question about this.

I agree with everything in your brief about the common law, the equities, the fairness, but the statute never says anything about void or voidable, but the statute does say, an individual may not waive this claim unless the waiver complies with the statute, and in this case the waiver did not comply with the statute.
If they do not come up with the money to pay you in advance, is it not true you claim you would have a defense to the suit which would be a waiver?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --If they do not pay it... no.
No, no.
It's not the waiver argument.
What we're saying is that they've forfeited their rights as a matter of common law by their failure to comply with an independent State law duty to tender back the consideration.
It doesn't revive the waiver.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: What is your defense to the suit?
Is it not the document that she signed?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: No.
The... it's not.
It is the failure to tender back, and the failure to pay the consideration.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Why should she have to... what in the statute compels her to tender anything back?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Nothing in the statute compels her to tender it back.
It is a bedrock principle of the common law and contract law.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: You say she has not... you say there's just no waiver issue at all, then.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: I've lost the waiver issue, Your Honor.
That's right.
She is perfectly available to come forward into court and bring her claim.

We do not fear, and I don't think any of the employers in these cases fear having these age discrimination cases go forward if that's what they want to do, but what we are concerned about, and what the common law protects, is our right to say, look, you have to put the money in.
That's the consideration you have to pay as a condition of coming in.
That is a wholly independent legal requirement that's been embedded in the common law for 200 years.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But if she had never signed a contract she wouldn't have to do that.
If she'd never signed the waiver she would not have to do that.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: If we had given her money in return--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Say she signed no document whatsoever, and you just said to her, we think you've been a wonderful employee, we don't think you're going to sue us, here's a lot of money.
Would she have to give that back?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --Of course she'd have to give that back.
The point is, is if you want to get--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: To bring an ADEA suit?
Why?
If she never signed a release she wouldn't have to give anything back, would she?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --As I understand the State common law--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Would you... I'm asking you, would you have a defense to this case if she had not signed a release?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --If she had not signed the release.
No.
Ultimately we--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: So the heart of your defense is the fact she signed a document that she has not rescinded.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --No, but that's not... no.
No, Justice Stevens.

The heart of my defense is that the common law recognizes an independent obligation, apart from whether the release is waived or not waived, that you must as a condition of coming to court pay back moneys that have been paid to you as a part--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: If you want to avoid a release.
That's what... the payback is in order to make something that is voidable... keep it alive.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --You can construe it that way, but that's not the way the common law views it.
Common law imposes it as an independent--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: I agree with you on the common law entirely.
My question is, how can you get around the statutory language that says she may not waive unless you comply with the statute, and you're saying she did waive?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --I will go back to the Court's opinion in United States v. Olano, which draws a clear distinction between waiver, which is the knowing and voluntary relinquishment of a known right and the implications of that, and it's a narrow concept, and a forfeiture of your rights which arises because you don't fulfill your independent common law duties, and that's what we have here, is an independent common law duty to put forward the consideration.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But that duty would not arise unless she'd signed a waiver.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: That--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Mr. Phillips, your argument does not assume that the waiver is valid.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --No.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: It just assumes that the waiver was signed.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Correct.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Isn't that quite different?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Yes.
You're right.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: It's essential to your case that she signed a piece of paper.
It is not essential to your case that that waiver be valid.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: That's correct.
Indeed--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: But it--

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --Indeed, we readily concede that it's an invalid waiver.
It's just not void.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --It's essential to your case that she signed the piece of paper, and that the piece of paper has the effect that Justice Stevens has been positing in his question.
The signature is not a mere incidental fact of history.
It has an operative effect.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: I understand that, Justice... Your Honor, but the bottom line here, the problem with that is, is how far are you going to take statutory language to do damage to the common law, and basically what this Court--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Or you might pose the question, how far are you going to allow a common law process in effect to thwart the statute, and if, in fact, we are correct in the intuitive assumption that has been suggested here, that in most of these cases in which this is going to be a serious question the worker is simply not going to be in a position to make the tender, then, in fact, on your theory the statute is a dead letter.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --Well, let's step back for a second, because that is... there is no support anywhere, empirical, that I know of, that that's true.
I mean, the principle of tender-back has been available for 200 years.
There's not a shred of evidence anywhere--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Yes, but the statute hasn't been.

I mean, we're in this position because we've got a fairly unequivocal-looking statute, and the fact that the common law may have operated without the hindrance of statute for 200 years leaves us, I think, exactly where Justice Stevens is.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --Well, no, but there have been principles by which one can void or declare unenforceable contracts for 200 years, and there has been a tender-back requirement that applies to that.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: But the tender-back--
--Well, what was the common law, though, if it was void?
Was it the situation that the parties might be left where the law found them at the time it was voided?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Yes, that is my general understanding.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: So there might not be a tender-back requirement.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Right, if it... if--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: If it were totally void.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --That's correct, if it's totally void.
On the other hand, there is not a shred of evidence that Congress intended to declare these totally void, for the reasons I think Justice Breyer's agrument describes--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: But your argument depends upon our determining that the waiver is voidable.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --That's correct, Your Honor.
If it's voidable--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: And if, in fact, it's void, we're faced with something else.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --That's correct.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Why--
--Again--

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: I agree with that, because--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --In response to Justice Stevens' point that I still think we'd better get straight, if we're the trial court, you don't say that the suit cannot proceed because the money was not paid back.
You say the suit was not... cannot proceed because (a) the money was not paid back, and (b) that allows you to plead the waiver.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --That's correct.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: But the statute says the individual can't waive.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: But the point of the ultimate... the significance in terms of how the law operates, and it's true in Louisiana as it is in every other State, that is, if... you know, the fundamental principle is, you pay back as a condition.

It is true that I... they... I have both components of it, but the part that precludes you from going forward and has precluded plaintiffs from going forward for 200 years is the failure to tender back the consideration.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Mr. Phillips--
--But not under Federal statutes like the FELA.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Well, the FELA is exactly on point in my favor on this, Your Honor, because there the language of section 55 says as plainly as possible any contract or device to limit the liability of an employer is void, and it says it in so many words.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But that's significant in this case for another reason.
This waiver is void only insofar as it waives FE... ADEA claims.
It doesn't purport to make the entire document void.
It just says it cannot operate as a waiver of this particular cause of action.
So it's void pro tanto.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Well, that goes back to Justice Scalia's question about severability.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Your point is that the FELA language about void does not find a counterpart in the ADEA.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Exactly.
Congress had a model it could follow in this context.

It had not only a statute that describes the matter as void, it also had a decision of this Court that enforced that statute in a way that eliminated the tender-back requirement, and Congress didn't follow that model here.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But there's a very good reason.
It did not want to create the specter that Justice Breyer's example creates of creating everything void.
It just said it's void insofar as it affects this particular claim.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: But it doesn't--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: It didn't say void.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --It doesn't say that either.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: It says, it shall not operate as a waiver of this narrow claim.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Right.
It seems to me Congress knows how to--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But you can't give effect to that language, as I understand your position, and still say she has to tender back.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --But Your Honor, if the position of the common law would have set aside the contract for reasons of coercion or duress or fraud or any of those other reasons, it's still, under those circumstances, no more than voidable, and so it would seem--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: We have an example, Mr. Phillips of State law... of a State law that says may not waive, do you agree that that's... the essence of this case is for us to construe what those words mean, may not waive, and I take that to be an instruction to the employer as well as to the employee, so may I ask you to respond to the question that I put to Ms. Haynie?
That is, one way to look at what Congress did, these words, may not waive, is to say, well, that's a condition, that whatever else this contract does, it can't do that.

The employer doesn't have the power to put it in, the employee doesn't have the power to agree to it, so the contract... the employer knowing that full well, by the way... the contract then must be construed to waive the host of other claims that are waivable, and it's enforceable to the extent that it doesn't include the one thing that Congress says thou shalt not.
So it's perfectly good to waive title VII, to waive a slew of other claims.
Why isn't that the most sensible reading of the may-not-waive language?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --Because the language has to be... I mean, you can look at may-not-waive on its own, but the truth is, it's a part of a provision that is designed to modify a very discrete element of the common law.
It eliminates the requirement and the burden on the employee to come forward and prove fraud, duress, or the other conditions that would justify setting aside a release.
Congress said, we're not going to put employees to that burden.
We are going to eliminate that obligation.
We're going to lower the burden that otherwise would exist.
But beyond that, Congress didn't say, and in addition to that we mean to eliminate through the language, waiver, all other forfeitures of rights.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: No, just may not waive this one claim.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: But this one claim is--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: And you think they can waive... they can waive it?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --No, of course not.
I'm not saying... they're not waiving by failing to tender back.
That's not a waiver.
That is, as this Court said in Olano, a forfeiture, just as she's not waiving if she fails to satisfy a statute of limitations or other restrictions on the ability to go forward.
The fact that she doesn't do that doesn't trigger 626 as a set of conditions on that forfeiture, even though we might colloquially describe that as a waiver.
That's not what Congress meant in 626.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Mr. Phillips--

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: The context is very narrow and specific.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --Mr. Phillips, I am surprised at your concession that if this contract is void the employee can keep all the money that he received.
You say that that's the common law rule?
I know that contracts that are void for reasons of public policy--

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --If I hire you to murder someone and give you money, I can't get my money back, or--

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: That's what I thought the question--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --if I pay you to fix prices or something like that.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --Right.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: But where a contract is void because the deal between the people is not... for example, void for want of consideration.
I give you money, and you've made an illusory promise in exchange.
Can I get... that's a void con--

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: No--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --Can I not get my money back?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --No, I was using void in the much more stringent term.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well, I--

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Which is the one I think that the question invited, was--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --Well, let me put it to you squarely.
Do you... are you concerned about the things that Justice Breyer is concerned about?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --Of course.
I think those are fundamental reasons why you would not interpret this language--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Then you can't say that a void contract leaves everybody where they are.
It depends on the basis for the voidness.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --No, you're absolutely right.
All I was answering was that as a matter of the... there are common law rules in which a particular finding of void leaves you without any ability--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Not every void--

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --No, you're right.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --And this is not one of those, so in this case I take it your position... is it your position in this case that if this Court holds that the entire waiver is void, that any employer can sue to get the entire... in effect can sue to rescind the contract?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: I would assume that that follows quite naturally.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: All right.
Now--

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: And frankly I haven't heard word one from the other side to counter that.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --My question is... and I don't know the answer to this.
I wish I'd thought of it before argument, but my question, then, is this.
If I can remember back to first-year contracts I thought rescission was an equitable remedy.

Wouldn't the court, if I'm right, simply say to the employer, no, you can't get the entire consideration back because they waived a lot of... if this is true, you know, they waived other things besides the age claim, so I'll give you part of it back.
I will come up... in effect, I'm going to do an intellectual... an equitable slice here.
Is that possible?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: No, that... no, and I don't know who taught you first-year contracts, but my understanding--
[Laughter]

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: He was very good.
The pupil wasn't, but the teacher was okay.
[Laughter]

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: But my understanding of first year contracts is that if you come forward you have to bring back the entire consideration, and that is clearly the law--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Wait... wait.
Can I just go right into that, because my professor was Jack Dawson, who was a fabulous first-year--
[Laughter]
Any failing is one of my own memory.
But the... my belief... I thought of this, is, there is no contract.
We don't have to rescind it.
There's a contract, but the provision at issue is void... it's not there.
Forget the word void.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --I would say voidable.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: It's invalid.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Invalid, un--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: It's gone.
Pretend it isn't there.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --Correct.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: At that point, we have a human being called a worker who has some money that the employer paid him, and I would have guessed, because I don't remember the course that well, that he is entitled, the employer, to get back the money to the extent that the employee has been unjustly enriched, and I would think that he has been unjustly enriched only to the extent that he received money for a promise not to sue which is invalid, i.e., only in respect to the ADEA claim.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: He--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: And therefore, what happens all the time in unjust enrichment, we have difficult questions to look into, and therefore he wouldn't get back [dollars] 6,000 here.
He would get back a proportionate share.
No.
The employee would have to give... why not?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --Well, I mean, that is a rule that could have been adopted, but it is not the rule that was adopted--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Where?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --and I think the reason is is because these are difficult--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Which rule wasn't adopted where?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --The tender-back requirement requires you to tender back the entirety of the consideration.
If you--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Entirety of consideration for what?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --For the severance that you signed.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, but severance only if the--
--But that's on the assumption that it's voidable, and the assumption of the question is that it's void.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Well... no, we didn't... no, that's not true, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: I'd--

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: The assumption was that it is unenforceable.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --All right, I'll take it... I'll go to voidable, and--

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Right.
[Laughter]
So if I'm right about the assumption that it's voidable, and I think I was right about that, then the common law rule... because voidable's one that arises all the time.
You get it in fraud and coercion, et cetera.
It may apply to a part of the agreement, it may apply to all of the agreement.

The rule of tender-back, as I understand it, and again I may not have had the greatest first-year law professor, either, but as I understood the rule is, you have to tender back the entirety of the consideration.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --The entirety of the consideration for?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: For the underlying dispute between the parties.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: For that portion--

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: No, I don't think it is.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --In other words, if he was paid [dollars] 10 million as part of a golden parachute, and the entire... and just in that golden parachute contract, which is 48 pages long, there's only one line talking about a promise not to sue, he has to give back the whole [dollars] 4 million, or [dollars] 10 million?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: It seems like an unjust result, but as I understand the basic hornbook rule... I'm not saying there couldn't be exceptions that would exist, but if you're looking for the hornbook rule, and the rule as it exists in Louisiana, at least in cases that don't pose that question, it's pretty consistently that you bring back the entirety of the consideration, and let's be--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Mr. Phillips, I used to teach first-year contract--
[Laughter]

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --I must say I'm happy I--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: He was not my teacher.
[Laughter]

And I don't know what the rule is generally about returning the whole thing or not, but I'm sure that where a contract contains several items, and the value all of those items depends upon future contingencies, you cannot await for... wait for one of those contingencies to occur, such as the bringing of a lawsuit, the discovery of a claim, and then say, well, you take back all the rest.
Give me... you know, I'll give you back only the money I paid for the four horses that didn't win.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --That's correct.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: And the one horse that did win, I only paid 20 percent of the whole thing for that ticket.
I am sure that a court would not allow that.
I'm not sure you have to go as far as the general rule you're pressing on the court.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: No, and I don't mean to press that rule, and I ought to step back, because it seems to me what this tells us is you ought to look to the common law, and you ought to see how the States apply these principles rather than--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I'm interested in that.

Now, what are you asking... I'm not sure how much difference it makes in this case, but just as a matter of curiosity, I wasn't clear from your brief, are you asking us to look to the law of a particular State here?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --No, although that might be a suitable vehicle for deciding this case, but as it happens the law in Louisiana is exactly the Federal common law, law rule, and so it doesn't make any difference.
In terms of the basic principle, is there a tender-back rule--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: It's nice to know what we're doing.
I mean--
--May I--
--Well, you don't think that Congress was enacting this law in the back... with the backdrop of State common law--

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --Oh, absolutely.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: --to several questions--

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Absolutely.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: --that it didn't cover in the statute?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Absolutely it did, but the real question is, if you--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, do you think... are we really dealing here with whether we should construct some principle of Federal law to fill in a gap?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --No.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Is that what we're talking about?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: No.
What we do have is a Federal question to decide where you look to the law, and my instinctive reaction is that you ought to look to the principles of State law and borrow those principles.

In this particular case, however, it makes no difference, because Louisiana, like the law of every other... all 50 States, and if there were a Federal common law rule what would be the Federal common law rule--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: May I ask--
--And you say that under the Federal common law... we have two cases.
Case one, there's a release that says ADEA release, but it doesn't comply with the statute.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --Right.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: The other case is a case like this in which, let us say, there might have been some substantial State law claims that were released as well as the ADEA claim.
It also is void.
You say the two cases are exactly the same.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Yes.
I think they should... well, they're not the same in... with respect to being able to waive the rights, sure.
That... the statute takes care of that.

But with respect to the obligation to come forward and satisfy the tender-back obligation as an independent, legal obligation that the State common law and, frankly, Federal common law applies, yes, those are exactly the same.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Mr. Phillips, can I ask you another question?
I also took contracts in law school by the way.
[Laughter]

Supposing one reads the statute noting that it doesn't use the word void or voidable, they're simply saying that when you have a release which purports to release 19 different claims, and if one of those claims is an ADEA claim the release shall not be enforceable insofar as it purports to release that claim, because that would be a waiver... they don't even talk about void or voidable... why wouldn't that be a reasonable reading of this statute?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: Well, that doesn't answer the question, though.
I mean, it's a perfectly reasonable answer.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: What question doesn't it answer?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: It doesn't answer the question whether you have an obligation to tender back as a precondition--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: It says it shall not be enforceable, period, regardless of whether you're able or willing or not to tender back.
Doesn't... isn't it perfectly clear what the mean... and isn't that a fair reading of the plain language of this statute?

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: --No, because that gives a meaning to the word waiver that is much broader than that term is entitled to carry.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: The meaning is, it shall not be enforceable as to that narrow claim.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: carter_g_phillips
turn.label: Mr. Carter G. Phillips
